title: How to Choose and Care for Wooden Spoons

steps.headline: Choose the wooden spoon(s).
steps.description: When selecting your wooden spoon, always look for those made from hardwood, such as teak. These spoons will be stronger and more durable than ones made from pine or other softwoods. Softwood wooden spoons will crack, split, and can absorb aroma and moisture easily. Spoons that become taunted with strong flavors, such as garlic, can ruin a delicately flavored dish, or even a drink like lemonade. If you're not sure what type of wood the spoon is made of, ask. A good retailer will be able to tell you and understand why you're asking. Think about supporting a local craftsperson who make such spoons; they will undoubtedly use quality hardwood, the finishing will be lovelier than mass-produced ones, and you'll be helping to keep their craft alive.

steps.headline: Keep the wooden spoon(s) clean.
steps.description:
The best way to wash a wooden spoon is to clean it immediately after use, using warm, soapy water. Don't use abrasive cleaning sponges on it, just soft sponges. Don't immerse wooden spoons in water for more than a few minutes when you're washing them up. Stand wooden spoons up to air dry. They should be thoroughly dry before you put them away. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/95\/Choose-and-Care-for-Wooden-Spoons-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Choose-and-Care-for-Wooden-Spoons-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/95\/Choose-and-Care-for-Wooden-Spoons-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Choose-and-Care-for-Wooden-Spoons-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Store your wooden spoons properly to preserve their beauty and extend their life.
steps.description: Wooden spoons can be kept in the drawer, preferably with other wooden and soft utensils. Avoid storing with metallic utensils as they might dent the wood. Alternatively, store the spoons standing up in a utensil container – this can be a particularly effective look in a country-style kitchen.

steps.headline: Consider resurfacing your wooden spoons.
steps.description: If the surface of your wooden spoon becomes rough, you can refurbish it with a 320 grit sandpaper or an unused steel wool pad. Rub the sandpaper or steel wool pad along the grain, continue until the surface is totally smooth. Thoroughly rinse the spoon in water the dry immediately with a tea towel.

steps.headline: Oil your wooden spoon to protect the wood.
steps.description: Oils moisturize wood and provide a protective barrier. Any non-toxic oil can be used to treat wooden spoons. Use mineral oil, almond oil, walnut oil or coconut oil. Saturate the wood thoroughly and leave overnight. Rub away the excess oil, paper kitchen towel is good for this. Treat your spoons when the look dull, doing soon will keep them from absorbing food stains and odors.

steps.headline: Use your wooden spoons for many cooking tasks.
Avoid using a favourite wooden spoon for scraping.
steps.description: Because wooden spoons don't damage non-stick pans and dishes, it's tempting to use your spoon when deglazing a pan. You can use any wooden spoon you like to do this of course, but it's tough on the spoon and can lead to cracking if you get too physical. Purpose made scraping spoons are available from specialist cookware suppliers.
